title: 114_hr6510
content: The "Save the Children Act of 2016" is the short title of this legislation. Congress expresses its sense through this act. Congress acknowledges the humanitarian crisis faced by Syrian children due to civil war violence, leading to their displacement to refugee camps. There is a willingness among various entities in the United States to provide temporary support to these young child refugees during this crisis. Congress acknowledges the humanitarian crisis faced by Syrian children due to civil war violence, leading to their displacement to refugee camps. Efforts are being made to facilitate the temporary relocation and immediate care of up to 25,000 young Syrian minor children refugees in the United States over a period of three years. The Act aims to relocate up to 25,000 young Syrian child refugees to the United States over three years. Efforts will be made to reunite or relocate them back to Syria once violence decreases and displacement reduces. The Save the Children Program, as outlined in Section 3 of the Act, aims to relocate young Syrian child refugees to the United States with the goal of reuniting or relocating them back to Syria once violence decreases. The Save the Children Program aims to grant visas for young Syrian children aged three to ten to enter and stay in the US until there is a significant reduction in civil war violence and displaced inhabitants in Syria. After this designation by the Department of State, there is a six-month grace period before the visas expire. The Save the Children Program grants visas for young Syrian children aged three to ten to enter and stay in the US. There is a six-month grace period before the visas expire, allowing time for due diligence to identify proper guardians for reunification with families. Only qualifying children with established guardians present to relinquish custody or orphaned children are eligible for the visa. An Office of Coordination is established in the Office of Refugee Resettlement for this purpose. Establishment of the Save the Children Program Coordinator in the Office of Refugee Resettlement of the Department of Health and Human Services with supervisory authority for operations in the US. The Coordinator is appointed by and reports to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Staff appointments require approval from the Office of Personnel. The Coordinator of the Save the Children Program in the Office of Refugee Resettlement of the Department of Health and Human Services can appoint additional personnel with approved pay, including private citizens or non-Federal Government employees. Federal departments or agencies may detail personnel upon the Coordinator's request. The Coordinator of the Save the Children Program in the Office of Refugee Resettlement can appoint additional personnel with approved pay from Federal departments or agencies to assist in carrying out duties under this Act. The Coordinator of the Save the Children Program in the Office of Refugee Resettlement is responsible for identifying and qualifying young minor children for the Program, including obtaining custody from guardians or establishing orphan status, and facilitating their temporary resettlement in the United States. The Coordinator is responsible for implementing the temporary resettlement of young minor children in the United States, in accordance with laws, international agreements, and domestic security interests. They will work with approved organizations and government authorities to carry out the program. The Coordinator collaborates with government authorities to implement the Program for resettling minor children in the United States, ensuring compliance with laws and international agreements. The Program for resettling minor children in the United States will terminate six months after certification by the Secretary of State, based on specific criteria related to civil war violence in Syria and displacement of Syrian inhabitants. The Program for resettling minor children in the United States will end six months after the Secretary of State certifies a significant reduction in civil war violence and displacement of Syrian inhabitants. The Program for resettling minor children in the United States may be suspended or terminated if the President determines it is necessary due to foreign circumstances. The Program for resettling minor children in the United States may be suspended or terminated if the President determines it is warranted by foreign policy and domestic security interests. Appropriations are authorized for each fiscal year as necessary, and funds can be used from the Migration and Refugee Assistance Act of 1962. A reporting requirement is due within 180 days. The Coordinator must submit a report to Congress within 180 days detailing the implementation of the Program for resettling minor children in the United States. SEC. 4. TEMPORARY NONIMMIGRANT VISA. The Program shall admit up to 5,000 alien minor children aged three to ten in the first year, and 10,000 more in each of the following two years. Preference will be given to children already in custody of the US or its allies outside Syria. This amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to include a Temporary Nonimmigrant Visa. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a Temporary Nonimmigrant Visa for Syrian residents or those born in Syria until the Secretary of State certifies a reduction in civil war violence and displaced inhabitants. The Syrian Civil War Minor Child Protection Act of 2016 applies to Syrian children between three and ten years old who are residents in Syria or displaced refugees, approved by the Secretary of State. The Save the Children Program allows aliens admitted to the United States to remain temporarily until certified by the Secretary of State. Aliens admitted to the United States under the Save the Children Act of 2016 can stay until the Secretary of State certifies a significant reduction in civil war violence and newly displaced Syria inhabitants, with a six-month grace period for reunification efforts.
